Award.AwardTitle: Conference in Stochastic Analysis and Related Topics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the conference "Stochastic Analysis and Related Topics" to be held May 20-22, 2015 at Purdue University. The primary goal of the conference is to provide a venue for researchers in probability theory to share recent advances in the field. The conference will consist primarily of talks by 17 invited speakers. This grant will help to cover the expenses of the invited speakers and also provide travel and local expenses for graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and other junior researchers attending the conference.

Much of the research in probability theory can be classified into one of two classes: 1) discrete probability models (random walks, interacting particle systems, models in statistical physics), and 2) stochastic analysis (stochastic PDE, diffusion processes, Malliavin calculus). The speakers in the conference are distinguished researchers whose work covers a wide array of topics in both discrete probability and stochastic analysis. The broad array of topics covered should provide a wonderful overview of the field of probability to the younger participants in attendance, and will also offer opportunities for researchers to form connections between different areas of research within probability theory.

The website for the conference is http://stochasticconference.wordpress.com/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funding was provided for the conference “Stochastic Analysis and Related Topics” held at Purdue University on May 20-22, 2015. The conference featured 16 talks over three days on a wide variety of areas within probability theory. There were over 90 participants in attendance at the conference, including 35 junior researchers (graduate students, postdocs, and recent PhDs) who were able to attend due to the support from this NSF grant. The conference provided opportunities for participants to learn some of the latest results in probability theory. Participants also were able to meet and interact with other researchers from all over the United States and the world. The wide diversity of topics covered in the conference allowed for participants to see connections between different fields that are currently of interest in probability theory.

 

The conference was organized in part as a celebration of the 60th birthday of Professor Rodrigo Banuelos. Professor Banuelos, in addition to being an excellent mathematician, has for many years been very devoted to promoting diversity in science and mathematics. The organizers of the conference therefore made a concerted effort to encourage the participation of women and underrepresented minorities. One result of this was that in addition to the regular conference activities, there was also a special dinner for the female participants during the conference to help form mentoring relationships for junior female mathematicians working in probability theory.
